error.signature: Error: A component suspended while responding to synchronous input. This will cause the UI to be replaced with a loading indicator. To fix, updates that suspend should be wrapped with startTransition.

verdict.summary: A React component suspended (threw a Promise) but there is no Suspense boundary ancestor to catch it and show a fallback UI, or a synchronous update caused a suspension that would replace visible content with a fallback. In React 18, components using React.lazy(), data fetching libraries with Suspense support, or the 'use' hook must be wrapped in a <Suspense> boundary. Without it, the thrown Promise propagates as an unhandled error.

dead_ends.action: Wrapping the entire application in a single top-level Suspense boundary
dead_ends.why_fails: A single top-level Suspense boundary replaces the entire application UI with a loading indicator whenever any component suspends. This provides a poor user experience because unrelated parts of the UI disappear while one section loads. Suspense boundaries should be placed close to the components that suspend for granular loading states.

dead_ends.action: Converting async data fetching to useEffect + useState to avoid Suspense entirely
dead_ends.why_fails: While this avoids the need for Suspense boundaries, it reintroduces the problems Suspense was designed to solve: loading state management scattered across components, waterfall request patterns, and the need to handle loading/error/success states manually in every component. It also prevents use of React Server Components and streaming SSR.

workarounds.action: Add a Suspense boundary with a fallback around components that may suspend
workarounds.how: Wrap the suspending component: <Suspense fallback={<LoadingSpinner />}><LazyComponent /></Suspense>. Place Suspense boundaries at meaningful loading boundaries in the UI (e.g., around each route, around each data-dependent section). For React.lazy() components, always wrap them in Suspense. For data fetching with Suspense (e.g., React Query, Relay, use() hook), wrap data-dependent sections.

workarounds.action: Use startTransition for updates that may cause suspension to prevent replacing visible content
workarounds.how: Wrap state updates that trigger suspension in startTransition: import { startTransition } from 'react'; startTransition(() => { setResource(newResource); }). This tells React the update is not urgent, so it keeps showing the current UI while the new content loads in the background. The Suspense fallback is only shown if there is no existing content to keep visible. This is essential for tab switches, navigation, and search results.

leads_to.condition: when the unhandled suspension crashes the component tree and triggers an error boundary
when the lazy-loaded chunk fails to download after the Suspense boundary is added

preceded_by.condition: when adding React.lazy without adding a corresponding Suspense boundary

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Missing Suspense boundary means no <Suspense> component exists to handle a thrown Promise (loading state). Missing error boundary means no ErrorBoundary exists to handle a thrown Error (error state). Suspense handles Promises; Error Boundaries handle Errors. A component may need both.
